timeline.bodyText:
Not always, to<AnotherClass>() is conventional for an instance of a class to transform to or provide an instance of another class. And in this case, the method name can be made more clear. Or, maybe, this is a very short code block, and creating a converter class is an overkill? But honestly, I don't grasp the overall design honestly, I am not sure.
And, perhaps this can be package-private? Let's start with limited scope. It's easy to make it public, but it's difficult to find methods with unnecessarily larger access.

replies.bodyText:
I agree, the naming was a little unclear. I modified the class name to be a bit more consistent with BuildFiles so that the method will be called in this format -> JarFiles.toJibContainerBuilder. But let me know if this looks okay? The method is very small now, but the plan is to eventually pass in JibCli options as another parameter, which will be used to set those extra image parameters (such as environment, etc.).
Ah since this method is going to be accessed in the com...jib.cli.cli2 package when we are containerizing the application after the jar subcommand is called, I decided to make it public. Do you think this change is a little premature? Or in other words, is it better to increase the scope only when we actually use it elsewhere.
replies.author: mpeddada1

replies.bodyText:
Hmm... what if this methods goes into JarProcessor? Do you have a specific design principle in mind where you wanted to separate it out?
And if it is certain that this will be called from a different package, we can leave it as public. I just wasn't sure and thought the possibility this may be called in the same package.
replies.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText:
That is an interesting idea. I could be thinking about this too early but I was slightly reluctant to make JarProcessor do too many things at once. Additionally, since we're also planning on adding more modes in the future, this would result in the class become pretty long - so I decided to have one class that does just the processing of the jar and another one that does the generating of JibContainerBuilder (and incorporating cli params in the future)
I totally understand that the class may seem a little small right now but once we have more modes + jar types, this class would probably need to do the following:

Get the mode from JibCli options (default would be exploded mode).
Call JarProcessor.determineJarType to determine the jar type.
Have some logic as to which JarProcessor processing method to call (either explodeJar or packageJar) based on the mode and the type of jar.
[In the future] Incorporate optional cli parameters.
replies.author: mpeddada1

replies.bodyText: That makes sense. I just felt that the name JarFiles is too generic and easily misunderstood as a general JAR file utility, where this is really specific to instantiate and configure JibContainerBuilder. However, even after thinking about the name for a long time, I can't really suggest something good. Otherwise, LGTM.

timeline.bodyText: Food for thought: these are certainly interesting things, and I guess the user should be allowed to configure them. Then we get back to the same question we had for the usual Jib build command. Originally, everything was through command-line options and we didn't have a "build file." This makes me think, maybe, the jib jar subcommand should also support a "build file." Then the layers field should probably be interpreted in a different way. I don't know.
timeline.author: chanseokoh

replies.bodyText:
Yeah, that's definitely an interesting option to consider. The advantage of this would be that the user would be allowed to configure these params without having write a really long command. On the other hand (maybe it is too early to tell) could this potentially blur the line between the jib build command and the jib jar command or cause some confusion? For example, if I need the build file anyways, I might be better off using the jib build command instead? --> I could be missing some viable use cases here.
This also makes me think: Since our general idea for the jar command is to require minimal user input, is it worth picking some optimal defaults (like workingDirectory or user,  for example)?
replies.author: mpeddada1

replies.bodyText:
if I need the build file anyways, I might be better off using the jib build command instead?

jib jar still does way more things, like optimally creating multi layers (especially having a more tailored logic for Spring Boot), setting an entrypoint with right classpath, etc. And I envision that it will provide a nice getting-started experience and cover simple use cases without having to write a build file. At the same time, it can also support a build file, so that people who need advanced and complex configurations can consider that as an option for convenience.
And definitely jib jar is designed to be Java and JAR-specific, so it makes sense to set optimal defaults for many configurations. I actually think we aim for that. We can be highly opinionated on that. Actually, we are already so by creating layers as we think is better.
